abstractive.text: The user interface designer described the technical functions of a remote and stressed the need for a user focused design.

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: this is a <vocalsound> brief run through of the um of the technical functions of the remote .

extractive.text: the presentation is uh already slightly obsolete

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: because I <vocalsound> had in mind something that would uh be i be aimed at controlling multiple devices
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: I've looked at <vocalsound> looked at a num <vocalsound> uh couple of other uh remote control models just for an idea of basic design principles . Um
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: <vocalsound> Um um basically the job of the device is to send commands to an appliance , in this case the television set .
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: Um and there's two main trends in th in the sort of design practice .
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: On the one hand <disfmarker> and this uh this particularly relates to its sort of earliest models where with you know i so so many buttons on it
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: Um giving you every possible function that the that the device has , the remote control controls .
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: it creates a rather user unfriendly interface .
extractive.label: ass

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: And on the other hand there's a user focused approach
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: that pares things down to just what <vocalsound> what is most likely to get used . Um <vocalsound>
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: and of course there is a certain amount of sort of loss of function here obviously ,
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: And so you go for something that's fairly intuitive to use ,
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: My own view is that we should definitely be going for a user focused design .
extractive.label: sug

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: Um but uh the pro <vocalsound> I think the problem with a lot of the sort of user focused designs that are about is that they sort of make assumptions in advance
extractive.label: ass

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: about what uh what a given user's going to uh want mo want to do from <vocalsound> want it to do most .
extractive.label: inf

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: something that's uh <vocalsound> something that is more programmable ,
extractive.label: sug

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: that uh perh perhaps has the full range of functions available to it
extractive.label: sug

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: but you can then specify yourself what you're most likely to want .
extractive.label: sug

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: um I liked Ebenezer's idea of including a joystick in that and uh possibly a sort of fairly minimal number of sort of function buttons ,
extractive.label: ass

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: you then have some sort of basic display on it
extractive.label: sug

extractive.speaker: A
extractive.text: so that if you're um sort of cha changing from different modes for the device it'll tell you just exactly what uh you know each direction of the uh of the um joystick's <vocalsound> going to do or wha or what each function button's going to do .
